Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Tomographic Particle Image Velocimetry (Tomo PIV) System for Multi-Disciplinary Research

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
An optical method of flow visualization, Tomographic Particle Image Velocimetry (Tomo PIV), measures instantaneous three-dimensional (3D), three-component (3C) flow velocity. This Major Research Instrumentation project supports ongoing research and education in fluid dynamics at several Penn State campuses and other nearby institutions. The project will enable new cross disciplinary collaborations among 15 researchers across the Penn State campuses and with fluid dynamics researchers at other institutions. The instrumentation provides unprecedented access to the details of the physics of turbulent flows, enabling fundamental research with a significant impact on the engineering, biology, mathematics, physics, and medical communities. The instrumentation will be incorporated into undergraduate courses and undergraduate and graduate student researchers will gain an understanding of experimental design, setup, data acquisition, and analysis using the high-tech Tomo PIV system. The researchers will provide tools for K-12 education and outreach activities, thereby increasing the public awareness in science and engineering and inspiring students to pursue advanced degrees or careers in STEM majors. The investigators will also engage students from underrepresented groups in their research.

This Tomo PIV system enables fundamental research in a variety of application areas. One study will examine the highly 3D nature of coherent structures in transitioning and turbulent boundary layers over oscillating geometries, with direct applications to flapping flight. The 3D Tomo PIV system will enable researchers to measure the complex velocity fields so that they can completely characterize the 3D behavior of vortex structures on flapping wings. Another project will conduct fundamental research to enable the development of cardiovascular devices with reduced risk of blood cell damage and clot formation. The Tomo PIV will enable researchers to better understand 3D cardiovascular structures and the influence of turbulence on cellular components and the formation of clots on surfaces. By capturing instantaneous complex flow structures, the instrumentation will enable the researchers to develop enhanced computational models to validate cardiovascular device design through improved understanding of the 3D velocity fields and shear stresses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Tomographic Particle Image Velocimetry (Tomo PIV) system purchased through this award, measures instantaneous three-dimensional (3D), three-component (3C) flow velocity fields. This Tomo PIV system dovetailed with ongoing research and education in fluid dynamics and facilitated productive multi-disciplinary collaboration among faculty members and researchers at different campuses. Many users, collaborators, and students received on-site training with the instrumentation. When the equipment was transferred to other campuses, undergraduate students helped with the initial setup and assisted the users to work with the equipment.

The main research conducted in the PI's lab investigated the gust-mitigation performance of flapping wings in simple motions and the flow physics of their interactions with gusty ambient flow structures. Fundamental understandings of the flow physics pertinent to the interactions between wing-generated and ambient flow structures, and how these interactions affect the mean and fluctuations of aerodynamic forces were investigated. In the next phase, the effect of turbulent flow on the pitching-plunging-rotating wings will be studied to understand the unsteady effects and three-dimensional/rotational flow effects on the gust-mitigation performance and the flow behaviors by comparing 2D and 3D wings. Both parametric studies and optimization using reinforcement learning methods will be applied.

The PIs have created new opportunities and excited many undergraduate students to use the Tomo PIV instrumentation and better learn fluid mechanics through experimental activities. It was a unique opportunity for undergraduates to be part of true discoveries that was enabled by this technology through theoretically intriguing and visually appealing experimental fluid dynamics. This instrumentation expanded the learning and research opportunities for undergraduate students who would not normally get to learn about this powerful flow measurement technique during their undergraduate education. The investigators also engaged students from underrepresented groups in their research. A new Integrative General Education (GenEd) course on flow visualization (PHOTO 321N) has specifically been developed for this purpose, in which students from all majors use the equipment for particle tracking visualization. In this course students learn photography skills as well as physics of fluid motion. They are introduced to the beauty and fascination of fluid flow, as well as exposure to the flow visualization techniques. The course objectives evaluated through students? work are "integrative thinking?, "creative thinking", and "effective communication". The equipment was also used to engage the K-12 students in STEAM activities such as flow visualization and PIV demo sessions to demonstrate both scientific and artistic aspects of fluid flow.
